videoSnippet.title: Ukrainian Chess Champion Requests Lie Detector after Being Accused Of Cheating
videoSnippet.description:
Read entire article here https://www.chess.com/news/view/fide-world-university-chess-championship-cheating-iulia-osmak
Watch all the games here https://chess24.com/en/read/news/cheating-scandal-hits-fide-world-online-university-championships
Have a great day :)

Osmak, Iulija (2428) - Badelka, Olga (2428)
FIDE World University Women's Online Rapid Championship (chess24.com) [1] 2021.03.25
D27 Queen's Gambit Accepted, classical, 6...a6

1.d4 d5 2.c4 dxc4 3.e3 Nf6 4.Bxc4 e6 5.Nf3 a6 6.O-O c5 7.b3 Nc6 8.Bb2 b5 9.Be2 Bb7 10.a4 b4 11.Nbd2 cxd4 12.Nxd4 Nxd4 13.Bxd4 Be7 14.Nc4 O-O 15.Bf3 Bd5 16.Nb6 Rb8 17.a5 Bxf3 18.Qxf3 Nd5 19.Rfd1 Nxb6 20.axb6 Qe8 21.Qg4 g6 22.Rxa6 Qb5 23.Rda1 Qd5 24.Qf4 Bd6 25.Qf6 e5 26.R6a5 Qxb3 27.Rxe5 Ra8 28.Rea5

00:00 Hello Everyone!
02:00 2017 Ukraine Champion!
02:32 Tweet Analysis
05:15 Game Starts!
06:34 Completely New Game!
08:50 Pause the Video!
09:35 It Was in This Position!
10:30 More tweets!
12:50 Contributions

Iulija Osmak scored 4.5/5 in the final of the Women’s Rapid section of the 1st FIDE World University Online Chess Championship, but her score has now been changed to 0/5, with Julia Antolak declared the winner. 23-year-old Osmak, the 2017 Ukrainian Women’s Champion, says she was disqualified based on a statistical analysis of her five games from the final and has expressed a willingness to take a lie-detector test to dispute that verdict. The Fair Play Panel of the event say 20 players in total were disqualified, but that they are not claiming “proof of actual cheating”.
